name: Dinner Date
description: Julian Luxemburg has prepared a dinner for two at his place – but things go awry when the date does not show up and he is left waiting at his dinner table, the clock’s ticking growing unbearably loud. „Dinner Date” is the character portrait of Julian: by becoming his subconsciousness you gain a clear vantage point on the worries which...

reviews.review_text: Forever Alone: The Video Game

I'm not sure what to say about Dinner Date, as there is nothing to it....  It's just another of those pretentious artsy 'games'.  The story is shallow, the graphics are nothing special, neither is the voice-acting. Basically there is nothing to do but listen to some dumbass talking, and randomly eating bread or whatever.  Save your time and skip this crap.

I think the developer should pay  me  for the time wasted playing this unfinished, 30-minute long, 'edge-of-your-kitchen-chair-excitement' non-game...  Got it in a bundle and I  still  feel cheated...  Avoid...

The idea for the game is interesting, the game's quality is good (great voice actor, very nice graphics), but there is not much meaning to this experiment. It would be a lot more interesting if our actions were meaningful to the story, and not a choice of what we eat first, or which side our character looks at, etc. So no, I cannot recommend this game, but I don't think it was a waste of time, as it is a short experimental game, and I enjoy fresh concepts. I'd love to see something better based on this concept.

Given all of the hype over this game, I was expecting something a lot better; not twenty minutes of aimless clicking to run through a boring and repetitive monologue that cannot be changed AT ALL by the decisions you make. I'm really glad this was a drunken impulse buy when it was on sale for <$1.00, otherwise I would be very disappointed that I wasted the money.

After finishing the game : Wut?  This isn't the 'game' for everyone.  This is like a pure art. The developer tries to get you into the feeling of having a dinner date, more specifically, a date that's not gonna happen.  There are 2 choices is this 'game', wait or follow. You can leave your computer in idle state, get a bath, take a nap and come back. I'm quite sure nothing will change in the game. Or you can follow the intruction-press the buttons as told to follow the story.  Soundtrack. This is a plus. It fits the environment and atmosphere very well. World Design. A heartwarming outdoor view got my praises.  Friendly Tips : Give it a try if its FREE. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. It is not worthy as a game('game').

This 'game' is approximately 20 minutes of a whiny, entitled idiot faffing about. Choices are irrelevant, having no effect on the ending or even, seemingly, the journey to get there. Even with that, fine -- I've played short and linear visual novels that I've enjoyed... But no. I have played free games with static graphics that have more compelling and meaningful narratives than this. I assume it is supposed to be deep or artsy; maybe I'm uncultured, but I have completely missed the point of this game.

This game almost made me fall asleep, I was hoping something exciting would happen. I thought maybe the japanese girl would barge in the door and they would make passionate love on the table. Unfortunately, this did not happen.
Not really a game (you can literally just wait) and not really interesting
Such amazing game.  Certainly owes us a sequel.

I was in the market for a bread eating simulator, and this did not dissapoint. You can pick up the bread. You can hold the bread. You can -dip- the bread. And, of course, you can eat the bread! After years of putting up with casual games like The Sims and Minecraft, hardcore bread eaters can finally have a game that really challenges them.   10/10 would bread again.
great simulator for my life

It is an unusual piece. I recomend playing it once, but only once. Whether or not this counts as a 'game' is not useful discussion, but regardless it remains an interesting experience. Do not buy this if you are expecting replayability, or to enjoy it for more than twenty - thirty minutes.

...well, I guess I've found the video game equivalent of getting stood up at the local chippy on a Saturday night.  You don't control anything; you're the subconscious thought processes of this self-absorbed Scandinavian hipster prick who's waiting for a pretty Japanese girl to join him for dinner at his house, all with the express purpose of getting into her Hello Kitty panties. Dude constantly moans - about his love life, his career, his friends (I can't believe he has friends), the soup getting cold, that hydrogen atoms only contain one electron, everything - and it gets incredibly monotonous just listening to the guy gripe his ♥♥♥♥ off, while not being able to do anything but glance at the wall clock, eat bread, get progressively more drunk (the guy is staggering after just three glasses of wine - lightweight), light up some smokes by the window (he's not even allowed to smoke in his own home. WHAT.), crick his neck, and other minor actions , all through pressing keys on the keyboard (though, if you leave the keyboard alone, he'll do his own thing anyway, so why even bother). And through all this, this pretentious cunny-dribble assaults the player with his odious opinions on friendship, love, his own feckless introversion, and how the japanese girl he wanted to 'shag', as he so charmingly puts it, is a ♥♥♥♥♥ for not turning up at his pokey little flat for nasty-looking bread, cold oxtail soup and, probably, a less significant dicking than even a Japanese flea is used to.  Well, I say good for Meiko. I wish I'd stood him up, too. As it is, I'll just have to remember this game as a boring night in.

Please don't buy this. This thing is completely non-interactive, You listen to a boring guy complain about his banal worries for 20 minutes and that's it. The characters mentioned in the description are too shallow to make this kind of thing even remotely interesting.
this sucks assdonkeyshit, but its probably the closest ill ever get to a real date

I have no idea how to rate this. I enjoyed it but I think it was because of how bad it was. The badass thing you get to do is double dip bread. Oh yeah I went there. I'm a badass. But properly reviewing this I have to say it wasn't that good. The biggest problem I had was how was I suppose to feel in the end of the game? It was funny to me but I knew that wasn't right so I guess I should feel sad because Julian can't 'Shag' his new girlfriend but that sounds stupid to even think that.  3/10 Its novelty prize worthy but I can see the potential for future games like it. Maybe some better dialougue, better setting, better interactivity and it will spawn a new idea of storytelling in video games. Until then have a drink and enjoy Julian's crappy mopping of being alone.

Twenty minutes - that's how long it takes. Reminds me of Dear Esther - you're more of a spectator than of a player here. Yet, even that, mixed with a couple of amazing ideas, turns out to be worth those 20 minutes of your life.  Also, ♥♥♥♥ Jerry.

So, not quite what i think the game was about. The game have no story interaction control whatsoever no mater what you do. You only can control some involuntary movements but the (boring esixtenzial) story always repeat itself.  Sure is a nice 'piece of useless art' but is nothing like a game. Is more like a first person movie where you have a realy limited interaction.  Maybe - and just maybe - a similar concept could work well with an oculus rift
Has no purpose in being a game, and no right in having a price tag. Calling it nothing isn't reductive; it applies to it entirely. Not even worth your time.

At the time of this review the user Korig perfectly describes my experience and issues with the game. Aside from that however, I take issue with what is stated in the About section of this game. It claims that controlling the subtle subconscious actions of the protagonist will resonate 'with Julian’s thoughts to form an absolutely singular form of intimacy.' Resonation is a reflexive action, which does not translate to this game. This game is idle animations and camera controls set to a monologue. If these animations and controls did in fact affect anything, this 'game' might have done something to that effect, but no, in reality, there is nothing to relate to in the pretentious character of 'Julian,' not his affinity for east asians, not his affinity for dinosaur comics or poetry, nothing.

The game is only about ten minutes long, tops. The interactivity is absolutely inconsequential. You're essentially paying to watch a voice actor ramble ENDLESSLY start to finish, while sitting down and staring at the wall. There's no plot, no exploration, no development of the character or environment. It's just an all around unsatisfying school-project that feels more than a little pretentious.
Best candidate for testing out Steam's new refund system

Where does one begin when talking about such a master piece as 'Dinner Date'?  I'll start with the obvious narrative. While, ironically so, the game is entitled 'Dinner Date' it doesn't infact supply a date. Maybe a subtle undertone on Julian's dancing with his thouight of religion and Christianity? One must ask thesmelves.  Second of all is the appealing visual effects. I was absoloutly blown away by the look of the food and cigarettes. I could feel my stomach filling as I dined alone, on my bread and wine. What a beautiful nod towards Jesus. I was blown away.  Lastly, I want to mention the dialogue. While not 100% clean, it really struck me in a deep way. Showed how much of a hard time the character is having. My daughters hamster died recently so she can relate.  This is a fantastic visual and audible feast and I'm going to present it to my Sunday School church group this week!
40 minutes of non-interactivity and a boring 'story'

This game should be rated as the dialog has very strong language and lots of sexual reference. It is a very depressing game and I didn't feel very connected to the character. Gone Home was done so much better with a sense of mystery. You can guess the date is going to go horribly wrong after the first minute of the game.
I really enjoyed the game. It's nice to play it after a while. The only thing I didn't like was the weird lookin hand movements. other than that the story is quite well done for what the idea is.

I just wanted to give Dinner Date a negative review, but the more I wrote, the more I realized, I should actually make a positive one. So, first things first: I actually enjoyed Dinner Date. Finally I can be lonesome, even in the virtual world! :)  The game, obviously doesn't come with its shortcomings-'short' being the keyword here. Like the description says, it is basically a 25 minute-very well recorded-narration on the life of Julian Luxemburg, who is, sort of, your avatar in this game, except he isn't but his subconsciousness is. This game is an experiment, how much elements of interactive story telling you can take away from it to still be interactive. And it actually left an impression on me. Not the interactive part, but the story, I could relate with the poor guy in a way too good way. The music is produced well and fits the mood perfectly.  On the graphical side, however, a lot more could have been possible. I am actually not sure, whether the author wanted it to be sort of realistic or more in a comic look. If the game shone on this side, I would not hesitate to recommend it for full price, however, you will probably want to look when it is available for a reduced price. I believe, experiments, such as this, should be supported and as such it is okay for this game to be free. And the author probably still needs to fully pay the voice actor and musician, so...  In the end, I imagine, this is one of the first games, where Steam refunds will be exploited, as there is practically no replay value. (I did replay it and enjoyed it a second time, but there was a long time in between.) So please, don't be a jerk and keep the game, if you appreciated it in any way-even if it just got you the realization, that you don't like this sort of games. :)
A very moving game, it made me reflect on the hardships of life. Please recommend this to your friends.

This is not a game; it's a sort of exploration in story-telling. You're allowed to perform a few simple actions such as eating a piece of bread, looking at a candle, or checking the time, but these actions do not appear to have any effect on the course of the story. You just sit and listen to your character's internal dialog until the game ends.
Clockwise and counter-clockwise soup-stirring mechanics.  GOTY

This is the video game equivalent of finding a flaming bag of poo on your doorstep. I just spent $.74 on this, joke's on me!   If you're thinking of suicide, play this game. You'll want to kill the main character instead.
Ate bread and got drunk 11/10
A relatively short game, but still a bargin for 74 cents. Recommend it.

Dinner Date is not a game, nor should it to be expected to be one. Rather its more of a story with visual accompniment and mild interactivity.  For what it was intended, it does a fairly decent job. It showcases the different mental stages a believable character goes through. You are privy to the neurotic ramblings of a socially-awkward nerdy would-be intellectual who seems to believe the only thing impoartant in life is 'getting shagged', and is confused as to why this is difficult for someone who doesn't like to go out.  You can tell he is in a circle of friends whom all have more fun than him, and works in a place where nobody respects himself, and the only way he can justify his own behavior is through the guise of being a poetry-loving intellectual.  In many ways it was more educational than fun. You see him go through stages of denial, self-pity, anger, exasperation, and discontent. But if you don't understand the significance of it all, you won't get anything from this 'game'.

Do not buy. This is not a pick your own adventure, this is not a game. It is about 30 minutes long, you play as a dude talking to himself. Did I say play, sorry I mean watching a loser be lonely and depress for 30 minutes. Game over. Worse of all the story is so lame and pathetic. I got it for 50 cents. And it is still not worth it. Don't get this game unless the developer pay you to play it.

in my opinion it's not a game, it's not fun, it's not interesting. I can't identify with the character or the emotional outburst he has over getting stood up. Speaking of which, that setting is not exactly a recipe for fun.

I was a little hopeful going into the game. Don't play it. This game is sort of a bit very not good :s They could have done a lot with the premise, for instance your subconcious thoughts could ACTUALLY change what happens in the game but they really dont and the animations (which is all the game is anyway) and graphics are really bad.

I'm all for experimental video games and interactive experiences and this game does have some interesting writing and music but unfortunately the player interaction is so unimpactful to what is happening in the game that there is almost not much of anything to do in the game but watch and listen.  I would have been just fine if this was a free experience but you actually have to pay for it and even as an enthusiast for the source material, I can't really see any justification for that. So play this if you find it for free or skip altogether. You're not missing anything too special.

I enjoyed Dinner Date much more than Dear Esther, a game of a similar genre - both are solely focussed on conveying a story. Dinner Date lacks in any gameplay at all though the story is somewhat favourable, as the protagonist waits for their date to arrive. I think this is an interesting experience and is worth a try if you are enjoy this kind of thing.
Like Gone Home but not $20 and actually kinda good.

Is Dinner Date a well-written experimental short film with game-like elements incorporated or is it a pretentious, uninteractive pile of garbage? While I tend to lean towards the first option, I certainly can't fault a player who draws the latter conclusion. I mildly enjoyed my handfull of minutes with this little indie game but it's certainly NOT for everyone...
This game is dull and pretentious, not even worth playing as a joke. Julian Luxembourg is just an annoying ♥♥♥♥, I can see why he got stood up.
If you liked graveyard... this is much of the same.. worth 1$ no more.

It's alright. I enjoyed it fairly well at least at first. However after taking a little time and having my two playthroughs settle in a little bit, I realize this is a game that seems to be made with the intentions of trying to make up for what would be very boring fiction by turning it into a 'game.' It's not quite a game, there is no losing state, and there's only one path you'll ever take. Is it mildly interestin? Yes. But I would only get it during a sale, and if you're in the mood for something that's this much of a one-way story, you'll find much better-written books and short stories. It is kind of an interesting experiment, but I'm not sure that's enough by now.
Overpriced, not a game and hardly art. Sure I'd love if there was some branching at all, instead it's 20minutes of not having to press buttons unless you want to while listening to recorded thoughts.
This ♥♥♥♥ is way too intense for me.

This is a game that catches your attention in the first 5 seconds.  Although this game is not as great graphic wise like other populair games from big companies, it does however have the power to capitivate you.  You are the consious of a guy, and it's really awesome to hear what he thinks. There are a lot of awesome stuff to do, and it's story lasts about the same as a Call of Duty Storyline... 20 minutes! 20 ENTIRE MINUTES!  Key features: Eating bread Drinking wine Getting frustrated  BUY IT NOW OR YOU WILL REGRET IT WHEN THIS GAME GETS ITS DLC!!!  Their new DLC that will soon launch will give the players the ability to actually DRINK AND WALK!  10/10 must buy!

The idea this game seems to present is a good one- to subtley influence the main character's actions by acting as their subconscious. Unfortunately the game fails to do any such thing, and makes it so any actions you make have no impact at all on what happens.   That aside, the most damning thing about this game is that it even plays itself. You can sit and watch the screen and the game will do tiny actions for you, making a significant point about just how insignificant any user input is in this game. In fact, this barely even qualifies as a game. It's more of an 'art' piece, if anything.   To make a long statement short, this isn't worth your money. After playing it I actually wish someone had slipped me a dollar and a half for my time. 0/10, no stars, 0% on Rotten Tomatoes, worst interactive movie of 2011.

This game has truly opened my eyes up to the world. The beautiful graphics, seamless animation, and above all the endearing story made for the greatest gaming experience of all time. Games such as Modern Warfare, Battlefield, and medal of honor should follow suit and incorporate some of the brilliancy displayed here. This game is my messiah, brought to me by the good lord himself. i came over 17 times over the course of playing it, and it then gave me a $100 dollar bill, ejected through my cd drive. If i had to give this game a rating, i would have to say infinity out of 10. 5 stars, and a round of applause, for the most innovative and brilliant game ever!
I don't. What is.  Why did.   Huh.

I want to be able to recommend Dinner Date - it's definitely one of the more unique game experiences to be found on Steam - but too early into it, you realize that you've experienced just about all the game has to offer, and you're left slogging through monologue after monologue waiting for things to move on.  I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing about it. I received it as a gift, and had not heard of it prior. I expected it to be a lame dating simulator, and it's probably the best praise I can give to say that it is not that. Instead, you play as the inner subconscious mind of young-ish man who's set up his small kitchen for a date. As he sits at the table and waits for his date arrive, you can influence his actions by focusing on different parts of the scene, all while listening to the man's thoughts as the night grows later and later.  Unfortunately, this gets monotonous very quickly, and you're stuck following a very linear path as you pick your way through all the interactive parts of the scene. It also becomes very obvious early into the experience what will happen, which doesn't help the game feel more like work than play.  It's too bad, because the premise is interesting, and it could have been enjoyable, even if only as an art piece. As it stands however, Dinner Date is too slow and predictable to be any fun, in my opinion.

Interesting concept, but falls short on way too many gaming aspects. To be fair though, I wouldn't call this a game, but rather an interactive experience. Although it gives you the illusion (at first) that your input advances the story that same illusion is shattered when you realize that you have to select preset choices to get new ones...   In the end I still liked the experience as it was odd & refreshing but felt more like a psychological tool than a game...   Buy it for 2 reasons : when it's dirt cheap and/or to show to skeptical people that games can be more than just run & gun like those blasted Call of Duty kiddie thingies...

Wow... Just... Wow... I can't even begin to convey how awful and poorly designed this 'game' is... This isn't really even a game, as all you do is sit for ~10-20 minutes and listen to the narrative of a really unlikeable British 27 year old forever-alone-bleeding-heart-piece-of-♥♥♥♥. Was I supposed to be able to connect to the protagonist on some deep level?  ... Because I sure as hell didn't make any connections here. This lacks the production quality of a proper game and feels more like it ought to be just a 10 minute 3D short, you add absolutely nothing to a short video by letting the person look around. The entire production just wreaks of mediocrity, and the most interesting thing about this game is that they are attempting to market their game in such a way that they can make money from this.  This is just laughable and gives me diarrhea at the same time.

Jordan Hampton groaned as a cellphone vibration woke her from much wanted slumber. Her sweet slumber was disturbed by an urgent case.  When she arrived at the crime scene she found multiple bodies all requiring immediate autopsy, those added to the backlog she already had meant she was certain that she was going to miss her and Donny's dinner date that coming evening.  Donny was understanding and forgiving when she cancelled. Being in the same field than her, he more than understood, though Ducky was working at the federal level so he got the benefit of an assistant whereas Jordan did not.  Jordan tried not to get upset about the rain check, but it was the second date they had cancelled in as many weeks. The other cancelation had been due to NCIS getting a case. Jordan was beginning to wonder if it was all a sign that despite her and Donny's affection for one another their jobs meant they were incompatible. She tried to force the negative thoughts from her head, and focus on her work.
Very dull. The dialogue, gameplay and atmosphere are executed at a mediocre level at best. I didn't care about the character, story or outcome. Happily left it behind at the roll of the credits.

My personal favorite cover based shooter, It's the complexity of Gears of War, with the polished feeling of open world adventure only truly comprable to Skyrim. Join the protagonist, Julian on his truly inspiring journey to find the perfeect qtgf. 10/10 would play again
Simple, simple enough to keep me enthralled for an hour.
Save your money, save your time. Even if it's on sale - I'd say get a burger instead.  This game feels more like a proof-of-concept than a fully realized game.

I got this game for free and I still feel like I deserve a refund. This is not a game, and it sure as ♥♥♥♥ isint art. I can only imagine the ♥♥♥♥ eating grin on the face of the person who made this crap as he collects monthly checks from people buying this trash. The single worst thing on steam, and im counting DLCs like ranger mode difficulty for Metro Last Light, or one of those 200 dollar packs for some garbage MMOs that will go under within a few years.
I'm ashamed i bought this. I don't know why i did but i did. You're the subconscious of a guy and nothing really happens... The game ends in 15 minutes... Yup...

Game won an award and looked like it might be interesting. This is the dumbest crap I have ever 'played.' All you do is listen to some idiot talk while moving his hands. This won an award? IT IS CRAP!
I have nothing to say except that this game is the literal worst.

This was an experience really destroyed by having any expectations and paying money.  I went into it really happy to see something like this, but man did it fall short. It is about 15 minutes long and there's basically nothing to do or affect. The subject matter was so banal that I spent the whole time waiting for a breaththrough that just doesn't happen.  I think it is also misleading by saying you 'become the subconscious' of the main character. Because you don't, you just hear it, and the only think you control is some conscious decision making (like pouring wine) and order of operations. In that way, it's a kind of interesting slightly experimental movie, but it's far from any roleplay possibilities offered by using a videogame over a short film.  I did like a lot of the visual design. The objects were well designed and the icons conveyed their points well while working with the theme. The acting was good.  I really wanted to like it. I think it's an interesting portfolio piece for all involved. But it's not worth paying for.

Normally I actually enjoy games like these. Games where not much happens. Games without enemies where you just explore. This can't even be called a 'walking simulator'. It's a nothing simulator. For me, it wasn't thought-provoking or moving or even interesting, like most of these types of games aim to be in place of traditional gameplay. If you're going to remove gameplay elements like combat, leveling, etc you need to replace with them *something*. A story is usually what developers go with. Here they decided to go in a much more experimental direction and just replace all gameplay elements - including story - with nothing. Also, the game is incredibly short (this might be good, though). The time that I have on record is exactly how long it took me to complete the 'story' without rushing. This should have been a free game and even then it would have been hard to recommend.
My friend gifted this to me because he obviously hates me.  Voice acting was awful, along with the dialogue and the entire game.
